{{Infobox person | name = Carl Anthony | birth_date = February 8, 1939 Philadelphia, PA | residence = Berkeley, CA | alma_mater = Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning, and Preservation | known_for = Environmental justice }}
'''Carl Anthony''' (born February 8, 1939) is an [[African Americans|African American]] [[architect]], [[regional planner]], [[social justice]] [[Activism|activist]], and author. He is the founder and co-director of Breakthrough Communities, a project dedicated to building multiracial leadership for sustainable communities in California and the rest of the nation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reimaginerpe.org/20years|title=Carl Anthony: Earth Day and Environmental Justice - Then and Now {{!}} Reimagine!|website=www.reimaginerpe.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> He is the former President of the [[Earth Island Institute]], and is the co-founder and former executive director of its urban habitat program, one of the first [[environmental justice]] organizations to address race and class issues.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.yesmagazine.org/issues/cities-of-exuberance/diverse-green-beautiful-cities-an-interview-with-carl-anthony|title=Diverse, Green, Beautiful Cities: an interview with Carl Anthony|last=Gelder|first=Sarah Ruth van|work=YES! Magazine|access-date=2017-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Early life == {{BLP unsourced section|date=January 2018}} Carl Anthony was born in a predominantly African American neighborhood in [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, PA]] known as [[Black Bottom, Philadelphia|Black Bottom]]. His parents, Lewis Anthony (born William Edwards) and Mildred Anthony (née Cokine), sent Carl and his older brother Lewie to B.B. Comegys, an integrated elementary school in which only about a dozen of the 300 students were African American, rather than the segregated school called Woodrow Wilson, which was only a block away from their home. They later went on to attend Dobbins Vocational School, where Anthony was enrolled in the carpentry and cabinet-making shop. His teachers were impressed by his drawings and suggested that he transfer to the architectural drafting homeroom, where he fostered his interest in architecture.
== Education == Anthony graduated from [[Columbia University|Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning, and Preservation]] in 1969. Upon his graduation, he was awarded the William Kinne Fellowship, a grant to enrich students’ education through travel. Anthony visited traditional towns and villages in [[West Africa]], studying the ways in which people utilized their few resources to shape their environments.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/CARL-ANTHONY-The-head-of-the-Earth-Island-2989472.php|title=CARL ANTHONY / The head of the Earth Island Institute's Urban Habitat Program is an environmentalist who strives to interweave the traditions of Martin Luther King Jr. and John Muir|work=SFGate|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>
== Early Career: Architect’s Renewal Committee and UC Berkeley == Anthony began his professional career in the late 1960s at the Architect's Renewal Committee in Harlem, one of the first community design centers in the United States{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}. Upon his return to the United States from West Africa in 1971, he relocated to California and taught at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] as an Assistant Professor of Architecture in the [[UC Berkeley College of Environmental Design|College of Environmental Design]], later becoming a faculty member of the university’s College of Natural Resources.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://iop.harvard.edu/fellows/carl-anthony|title=Carl Anthony {{!}} The Institute of Politics at Harvard University|website=iop.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref> In 1980 he left UC-Berkeley to work as an [[architect]] and [[urban planner]].
== Urban Habitat (1989–2000) == Anthony served as President of [[Earth Island Institute]] from 1991 to 1998. During this time, in spring 1996, he was an appointed Fellow at the [[Harvard Institute of Politics|Institute of Politics]], housed within the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]], at [[Harvard University]].<ref name=":3" /> Alongside his colleague [[Luke Cole]] at the California Rural Legal Assistance Foundation, Anthony founded and published the Race, Poverty, and the Environmental Journal,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mesarefuge.org/people/carl-anthony-2/|title=Carl Anthony - Mesa Refuge|work=Mesa Refuge|access-date=2017-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref> which was the United States’ first environmental justice periodical.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VJgYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163&dq=%22carl+anthony%22+urban+habitat&source=bl&ots=PfRhGmWKNn&sig=lQCSNBeZ-7G-ODxmza927wYgReg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKytbKi__UAhUEcD4KHVLVCFwQ6AEIggEwEg#v=onepage&q=%22carl%20anthony%22%20urban%20habitat&f=false|title=Activists Speak Out: Reflections on the Pursuit of Change in America|last=NA|first=NA|date=2016-04-30|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781349627592|language=en}}</ref> In 1989, Anthony founded Earth Island Institute’s Urban Habitat Program,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yuen|first=Eddie|last2=Bunin|first2=Lisa J.|last3=Stroshane|first3=Tim|date=1997-09-01|title=Multicultural ecology: An interview with Carl Anthony|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10455759709358748|journal=Capitalism Nature Socialism|volume=8|issue=3|pages=41–62|doi=10.1080/10455759709358748|issn=1045-5752}}</ref> the mission of which is to combine education with advocacy and coalition building to advance environmental and social justice in low-income communities in the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]], with [[David Brower|David Bower]] and [[Karl Linn]], and he served as the initiative’s Executive Director until 2000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt5m3nf4b2/|title=Finding Aid to the Urban Habitat Program Records, 1970-2001|website=www.oac.cdlib.org|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> Anthony directed various projects of Urban Habitat: * Bay Area Justice and Sustainability Project: developed and promoted a regional agenda for justice and sustainability while addressing planning policies that lead to inner city abandonment. * Leadership Institute for Sustainable Communities: leadership training program for land use policies and practices. * Transportation and Environmental Justice Project: advocated for changing the priorities of the Metropolitan Transportation Commission (MTC) and the Bay Area Air Quality Management District toward addressing the transit needs of low-income communities of color. * Brownfields Community Leadership Project: worked with leaders of low-income communities of color in the Bay Area to ensure Brownfields redevelopment addressed their needs. * Hunter’s Point Environmental Health Project: trained residents and community leaders in Bayview Hunter’s Point in environmental health, justice issues, and laws. Partnership with the Southeast Alliance for Environmental Justice and Golden Gate University Environmental Law and Justice Clinic. * Parks and Open Space for All People: worked toward revitalizing San Francisco Parks System by focusing on the needs of low-income communities of color, ensuring that a diverse range of people could have access to the parks.<ref name=":4" />
== Ford Foundation (2000–2008) == In 2000, Anthony joined the [[Ford Foundation]]. There, he served as Acting Director of the Community and Resource Development Unit. He was also Director of the Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative for seven years, and funded the Conversation of Regional Equity, a dialogue between policy analysts and advocates concerning racial justice and sustainability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://earthhousecenter.org/about-earth-house/|title=About Earth House - Earth House Center - Oakland, California|work=Earth House Center -- Oakland, California|access-date=2017-07-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Breakthrough Communities (2008–) == In 2008, Anthony co-founded Breakthrough Communities, a project of Earth House Center,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reimaginerpe.org/rpe/radio/anthony|title=Carl Anthony: Earth Day and EJ {{!}} Reimagine!|website=www.reimaginerpe.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> an advocacy nonprofit for regional equity and environmental and climate justice and is serving as the co-director.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbanhabitat.org/about/board|title=Board of Directors {{!}} Urban Habitat|website=www.urbanhabitat.org|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref> Anthony founded Six Wins, an initiative in the Bay Area addressing the mitigation of carbon dioxide emissions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbanhabitat.org/campaigns/6-wins-social-equity-network|title=6 Wins for Social Equity Network {{!}} Urban Habitat|website=www.urbanhabitat.org|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref>
== ''The Earth, the City, and the Hidden Narrative of Race'' (2017) == Anthony’s memoir, ''The Earth, the City, and the Hidden Narrative of Race'', addresses regional equity and [[climate change]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.newvillagepress.net/book/?GCOI=97660100341370&|title=New Village Press|website=www.newvillagepress.net|language=EN|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref>

Fall 1996. * “Ecology and Justice in the Global Age: Integrating the Vision.” ''Terrain Magazine''. Winter 1998. * “The Environmental Justice Movement: A Reflection and a Critique: An Activist’s Perspective.” ''Power, Justice and the Environment: A Critical Appraisal of the Environmental Justice Movement''. Ed. David Pellow. Diane Glave and Mark Stoll. University of Pittsburgh Press, 2005. * “Remembering Karl Linn, 1923–2005: Landscape Architect and Founder of the Community Design Movement.” ''Progressive Planning Magazine''. Spring 2005. * “Race, Place and the Humane Metropolis.” ''The Humane Metropolis: People and Nature in the 21st Century''. Ed. Rutherford Platt. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard, University * 1995: San Francisco Foundation, Humanitarian Award * 1995: KQED, Honoree, Black History Month * 1993–1996: Chair and Principal Administrative Officer, East Bay Conversion and Reinvestment Commission * 1993–1995: Founder, President, EDGE, Alliance of Ethnic and Environmental Organizations of California * 1991–1993: President, City of Berkeley, Planning Commission<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Carl-Anthony-has-spent-decades-as-pioneering-3158463.php|title=Carl Anthony has spent decades as pioneering activist|work=SFGate|access-date=2017-07-10}}</ref> * 1990–1998: President, Earth Island Institute
